subject: Art
title: Simultaneous Contrast
description: How surrounding colors change how a color appears.

hook.text: Place a gray square on a yellow background â€” it looks blueish. Place the same gray on a blue background â€” it looks yellowish. The gray hasn't changed. Your perception has.

buildup.text: Simultaneous contrast: your eye shifts a color toward the complement of its surroundings. Gray on red background appears greenish. Gray on green appears pinkish. The brain auto-adjusts.

discovery.text: This affects every color decision in a painting. A green that looks perfect on your palette might look completely different once it's surrounded by other colors on the canvas.

twist.text: Josef Albers dedicated his career to this phenomenon. His book 'Interaction of Color' proves that no color exists in isolation â€” every color is shaped by its neighbors.

climax.text: Always judge colors in context â€” on the canvas, not the palette. A color that looks wrong on the palette might be perfect on the painting, and vice versa.

punchline.text: No color is an island. Every color changes based on its neighbors.

quiz.question: What is simultaneous contrast?
options: Using two contrasting colors side by side
Your eye shifts a color toward the complement of its surrounding colors
The contrast between light and dark
